Absolutely brilliant level design.  That's what this game is about.  Story is alright but don't expect it to be in-your-face drama 24/7.  This is a game about fantastic atmosphere and you exploring the level.  Figuring out that one specific solution or finding that one specific item bring such a fantastic epiphany feeling when it happens.  This game is full of that.

If you want stat grinding, a soap opera story, or a heavy combat focus, this isn't it.  If you want amazing level and puzzle design with matching quality atmosphere then you need to play this.

The only possible downside is the usual adventure game trope of not knowing where to go occasionally.  Just go over the known areas you've been and keep searching, it doesn't take forever to find the way through.

reviewText:
Lara Croft is searching for an artifact called the Dagger of Xian but discovers that a mysterious organization is also tracking it. If she wants to be the first to reach it and prevent a catastrophic fate for the world, she will need to find the keys that will open the way... elsewhere than in China.

I must say that Tomb Raider II isn't perhaps my favorite game in the series, as I'm heavily influenced by the first opus and Anniversary. But the story is well written too. I mean, who doesn't want to follow her under the water or in Italy or in Tibet?

The gameplay is pretty much the same as the first game: you jump, you search levers, you move stuff and you shoot anything coming in your way. And Tomb Raider II has a major shift here: instead of the animals or the legendary creatures, your enemies are now humans. Many humans. Many crazy humans. And you're confronted to them more than the animals (true, you have sharks, dogs, even Yetis or spiders). I suppose that maybe, this shift may have contributed to the fact that I'm still clinging more to the first game.

But this game is also introducting vehicles for Lara: boat (well in Venice) and the snow bike which I had the most fun with. This is great to take ramps, to jump over pits or to race against the clock. That's also one of the main changes. Another new thing is the fact that you have allies in the game in the form of Tibetan monks. Don't hurt them and they'll let you in peace.

Tomb Raider II is also an improvement for Lara herself: she has more weapons (like an harpoon for example) if she needs to defend herself (and trust me, she will need them nearly all the time). But the best improvement is probably aethestic: she's looking more curvy than angular, though she's still wearing her regular outfit.

However, during the game, now, Lara changes also clothes. While the change is perhaps minimal, it's more realistic for the levels. It's just a little disappointing that she must find her way on a platform in the middle of the sea, where it's very very industrial. But generally, the landscapes are still sticking to the Tomb Raider"

reviewText:
Core Design's insanely successful sequel to the original, classic Tomb Raider (1996) is just more of the same. However, for some reason, this statement seems to often be taken as a negative one, whereas I just view it as more of a good thing. And that's exactly what Tomb Raider II is. Much more!

Let's start with aesthetics. The graphics are largely improved in comparison with the first game. Lara looks like an even more sexy bunch of polygons this time around, complete with larger and rounder breasts, which I assume took up 60%+ of the development time and budget. Lara also has a ragdoll ponytail, which would actually look quite good, if it didn't look like a three-section staff that could knock somebody out. It would come as no surprise to me if she was almost every teenage guy's wet dream back in '97. Moving on, we have video settings this time around! Yes, actual video settings, and I'm fairly certain the game runs without any emulators or graphical enhancements that weren't there in the original release. There's even support for widescreen resolutions, but I prefer to keep it at 4:3.

Textures and other models are largely improved, although for some reason all the male characters look incredibly wrinkly. I think they just started with Winston's model and built upon every male character from there. Finally, there's an improved lighting engine, which also plays a faily big role in the game itself, as well as being a nice visual enhancement. There's only one complaint here, and that's the FMVs. Not only do they have awful scanlines, but the game goes windowed in full-screen and it just looks wrong. However, when you compare that to the first one, where you'd have to alt-tab and the game would sometimes crash, it's not a big deal.

Sound-wise, it's not as good as the first, at least in my opinion. The main theme is a gutted remix of the original, but Nathan McRee provides a nice selection of short, dramatic pieces which generally fit each situation well. Lara's new voice actor is good, although for some reason they didn't replace all her lines from the original. Seems a bit odd. All the male voice actors are god awful though. Just awful. Funny, but still awful. Guns sound incredibly satisfying, and there's a larger selection of environmental sounds to add to the atmosphere.

In terms of plot, it's very simple; point-A to point-B. Lara hears of a legendary artifact called the Dagger of Xian, visiting China, Italy, and Tibet in the process to claim it. There's a couple of hackneyed villains here and there, but it's all very basic. If you want better stories, I'd player later entires in the series.

Nothing much has changed gameplay or control-wise; rather there's just been some additional things slapped onto the already solid gameplay to provide some variety. Levels are insanely long. Like, hours long. There's 17 levels in the game and it took me 24 or so hours to complete. I'm a slow gamer, but that's still insanely long for an action adventure-game. I've also noticed a large increase in difficulty from the first game, and the learning curve is nowhere near as smooth. It seems to be completely random, but all I can say is that I recommend you save after pretty much every puzzle; according to my end statistics, I saved 217 times. There's a lot of instant deaths, and to be honest it feels quite cheap, but I suppose that's why you can save at any time. Secrets have changed and are more rewarding, and completionists will love finding them all. The new weapons are awesome, quite frankly, and some, such as the M16, require some actual tactics to use, rather than just holding control and backflipping.

The use of newly added flares takes advantage of the aforementioned improved lighting system, as a lot of areas in the game are too dark to see without them, and it adds a nice extra element of exploration and discovery. Although you can use them underwater, which is kind of funny. Ladders and ziplines are also new, although the former are incredibly cumbersome, overused and slow, and the latter appears about 3 times in the whole game, so they really don't count for much in my book. As such, Lara comes equipped with some new manoeuvres, such as doing a half-turn in mid-air, and the animations for these are all just as fluid and beautiful as in the first game. Lastly, vehicle sections, which I was at first skeptical and hesitant about experiencing, are actually some of the most enjoyable parts of the game. It's a shame then, however, that like ziplines, they appear so rarely throughout the game.

So what's the verdict then? Well, Tomb Raider II is everything a perfect sequel should be. It's an improvement over the previous title in an abundance of ways, but at the same time, I think the game suffers a bit from a lack of overall fluidity and pace. For example, my personal favourite parts of the game are the first couple of levels and the last 5, whereas the middle section of the game is all basically indistinguishable, incredibly long and tiring. There's also a lot of backtracking, far more than in the original. This game requires a lot of patience, but I do think it is worth it. The added positives and negatives balance it out to be exactly as good as the original, which I suppose means that it fails a sequel. But that doesn't mean it isn't a kick-♥♥♥, sexy, hi-octane and lengthy adventure.

3.5/5

reviewText:
8 million times sold for the Playstation and PC: a milestone at its release, a nostalgic gem nowadays.Hint: At the end of this review you will find a TL;DR and a video section.

----------------------------------------------------------------

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ REVIEW]▬▬▬▬●
Tomb Raider II was designed by Core Design (since 2006 Rebellion Developments) and released by Eidos Interactive in 1997 for PC (Windows 95/98), Mac OS and Playstation. There was no necessity of DOS anymore like it was for TR I.
The plot revolves around the Dagger from Xian, a powerful object that can transform its occupier into an even more powerful dragon when stabbed in the heart. Lara Croft travels around the world to find and add this dagger to her collection. On her journey the young woman meets Marco Bartoli, the head of a mafia organization. He and his henchmen are on the same search and will try to hinder Lara to get to the dagger first.

Since the first Lara Croft game some noteable things have changed. First of all the graphics got an minor allround-improvement. While you can still count pixels and a lot of polygons that are used, the surfaces are smoothed and the surrounding light advanced. Also the appearance of Lara Croft changed, her hair is now a long plait and throughout her adventure she will wear different -to her surrounding fitting- clothes, e.g. for the underwater levels she will wear a wetsuite. Every level looks different and holds the atmosphere from the beginning till the end.

Besides of the graphics, the weapon arsenal got an advancement. Pistols, uzi and the shotgun stood the same, while the magnum from Tomb Raider I is exchanged into the automatic pistols. New weapons are the harpoon, with which the player is able to shoot underwater, the M16 and the grenade launcher as the most powerful weapon in the game. New are the flares too, which will light Lara's dangerous travel through caves and dark alleys.

Different to the first game of this franchise are also the two added vehicles like the snowmobile (in Tibet) and the boat (in Venice). With these the player can travel faster in the level as well as overjump wider gorges. Lara Croft got new moves, include a roll midair after a jump and a acrobatic dive.

Laudable is the possibility for unlimited saves that comes with the new game on all platforms. The player is now able to save at any point in the game, which simplifies the whole playthrough a lot. Besides the named changes the gameplay is still the same, a mix between solving puzzles, platforming and adventuring (& dying a lot!).

Apropos solving puzzles: The player has to stay focused all the time. When activating a button or a lever a new door will open but not always in your immediate proximity. Try to memorise the layout of the level and in which places closed doors hinder you from progressing. Be careful, not only human and animals will stay in the path of Lara Croft. Traps all around are threatening Lara's life most of the time at unpredictable places. This keeps the fun up but frustrates at the same time after the 10th death in a row. Yet, it is possible to play through all 18 levels without a guide and with a careful gameplay even without dying.

Since this game is a port from the Playstation the controls feel a bit clunky. The most weird part is the fact, that the whole game on the PC is played with a keyboard only. This hinders the player also from changing the camera angle, besides the possibility to move Lara's head. Players that are not used to the keyboard only controls will be frustrated, since most of the deaths come from the limited field of view. Once used to the controls this game will bring you many hours of fun, and rage likewise though.

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ RÉSUMÉ]▬▬▬▬●
Graphicwise and controlwise this game might be primitive compared to todays standards. Still, this nostalgic gem contains a lot of fun, while visiting Venice, China and other places. The fight against Lara's environment, the mafia organization and the hunt after the Dagger of Xian will fill hours of your time. I never played through the whole game once, so the levels starting from Tibet were an absolutely blind run for me. Lara died a lot, I raged a lot but still the curiosity how and if Lara will be able to collect the Dagger of Xian kept me moving on. For those who already played through the game, probably more than one time, this game is filled with nostalgia and always worth to play through it again and over again.

Fans of the Tomb Raider franchise should get this classic immediately!

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ UPDATES]▬▬▬▬●
Tomb Raider II is now available at PlayStation 3, and PSP (via PlayStation Network), iOS and Android with improved controls. More nostalgia on other platforms, yey!

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ TL;DR]▬▬▬▬●
[✔] Improved graphics compared to Tomb Raider I
[✔] New weapons, vehicles and acrobatic movements
[✔] Complete new enemies and 18 levels
[✔] Unlimited saves at any point
[✔] No DOS, steam version workes on all modern OS
[✔] Ported to modern systems such as PS3, iOS, Android

reviewText: My 10-year-old self and I can't recommend this game enough. It's classic puzzle-solving at its finest. In fact I'm pretty sure that playing it made me smarter. There's no AI holding your hand here, nor any obnoxious button graphics that flash on-screen and yell at you to mash the Y key to perform some entirely gimmicky and circumstantial roundhouse backflip to the face that you'll never need to do again. Just Lara and her lovably awkward polygons running straight ahead with the arms fully stretched out at a stiff, perpendicular angle to the body. On occasion, you can make her say No
date: in a charming British voice, over and over again, and then kill her in a variety of exciting ways.\n\nSerously though, the levels are rendered beautifully, leaving just the right amount to the imagination, and many of the puzzles actually require more than three brain cells to figure out. There are no journal entries offering fluff faux immersion
recommended:
no toggled map overlays to tell you where you are, and very little clues to help you out - just you and an often convoluted and action-packed pathway from the start of a level to the exit. The levels themselves, especially the memorable Venice series, have personality and often make you feel real suspense and a sense of danger. While some puzzles might frustrate the modern gamer (certain ones depend on very exact placement of Lara to perform a series of jumps with no room for error, for instance, which can get pretty tedious), the feeling of accomplishment you get after finally landing that horrendous jump, or opening that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ door, is so worth the effort.

In my opinion, this and the original Tomb Raider are the best installments in the series, mostly thanks to their simplicity. What it lacks in modern graphics, the game makes up for tenfold in gameplay and creativity of story and design. Plus, for the first time, Lara gets to use vehicles, which add a great deal of fun to the levels they appear in, by which I mean you can drive them off cliffs and explode.

All in all, you won't regret giving this a try. Yeah, you'll probably laugh at Lara and make fun of the dated graphics, and swear loudly at the controls, but these days, that's part of the fun. Definitely a must for 90s action/adventure gaming fans and especially people who don't mind video games not insulting their intelligence for a change.

Oh and you can lock the butler in the freezer.

reviewText: Many people complain that this game's controls suck and that it's so old it looks ugly. While the graphics aren't as good as the current games (obviously!) and some people might not be able to overcome this, I can't agree with the controls complaints. You need to understand that this game came out in 1997 when the current WSAD system wasn't the standard. Sure, it takes time to get used to the controls, but when you do, you will find out this is one of the most precise control systems.\n\nNow, finally to the review. I have very fond memories of this game and consider it one of the top games in Tomb Raider franchise. Great choice of locations (China, Venice, wreck of Maria Doria, Tibet), thick atmosphere and simple, but sufficient story...yes, there aren't as many movement options as in its successor, Tomb Raider III, but I never thought that matters. The only downside to this great game is the Steam port - what the flip is the problem with FMVs? They're all windowed and in small resolution. But other than that, this game is brilliant. If you aren't an impatient kind of gamer who hates games that really take some effort to finish, get it. It's classic and fun even today.

reviewText:
Tomb Raider II, released in 1997 is certainly a fascinating one. Following on from Lara's adventures in Tomb Raider, Lara finds herself in pursuit of a mythical Chinese artifact, The Dagger of Xian. Lara's journey begins at the Great Wall in China, then to the city of Venice, deep under the sea to the wreckage of the ship, Maria Doria, then to TIbet and finally back to China to face off against the leader of the Fiamma Nera, Marco Bartolli.

Gameplay is considerably like the first game, only Lara can now climb ladders, twist around in mid-air or underwater to face the other way, use flares to light up dark areas and carries a much bigger arsenal with weapons like the Grenade Launcher, Harpoon Gun and Automatic Pistols, whilst still maintaining weapons from the first, like the Shotgun and Uzis. Lara controls much better in this game, runs faster than in TR1, Lara also has a new voice actress replacing Shelley Blond, the more mature and rich voice of Judith Gibbins. Another thing to be noted is that Lara has several costume changes in-game, you start in the classic gear, later she changes to a wetsuit for the underwater levels, and finally dons a bomber jacket for the cold Tibetan Foothills before returning to the classic look for the final levels. Nathan McCree returns from the first game to compose the music, and it is chilling! The title theme is a very memorable one, but some of the music can really chill, even scare you!

This game is by no means short. It can be quite complicated, but with a good look around and a lot of thought, you can beat it! Highly recommend it, very essential game for any fan of Tomb Raider, good luck!

reviewText:
Picture yourself (back) in 1997. Sega was still in the hardware business, Microsoft hadn’t yet entered it, Bioshock wouldn’t be released for another decade, and outside Japan, PlayStation didn’t even have analog sticks. It was certainly a very different landscape to the industry we know today, but don’t be fooled; the year had its own type of first-class offerings to gamers at the time.

In 1997, Tomb Raider II was Blockbuster of the Year. The start of the year had already seen the western release of Final Fantasy VII, but, a thirty-hour-plus JRPG with a mix of 2D and 3D graphics and its hybrid take on turn-based combat, it was a slow burner. With Tomb Raider II, Lara was running, jumping, swimming, shooting, mowing down thugs on a snowmobile, all in 3D, all in real-time. It was a technical achievement unsurpassed in ‘97, and that would go unsurpassed until the following year, with the likes of Metal Gear Solid, Gran Turismo and, of course, Tomb Raider III.

If complaints about the early Tomb Raider sequels revolve mainly around them being too similar to the original, they’re probably true - but it’d be unfair to apply them to the first of these sequels. Tomb Raider II may have been Tomb Raider 1 on steroids, but with the original having set down so groundbreaking a formula, it made little sense to depart from it in the immediate follow-up. And while the core gameplay remains largely the same, Tomb Raider II does bring many new things to the table. From the introduction of vehicles that offer new dimensions in speed and mobility, to a bigger weapon arsenal of which no two are alike, Tomb Raider II is far more than a simple reskin. Even the graphical overhaul breathes new life into the game world, from little touches such as Lara’s full-length ponytail, to sharper textures and the inclusion of sky (a big deal in ‘97!). The result is a succession of characters and environments more rich and with more personality than ever before.

The settings and level design for these environments is also a step up from that of the original. With the exception of roughly a third of the game, Tomb Raider II trades the original’s ancient caves and catacombs in favour of the modern and the urban - Lara guns her way through an opera house in Venice, an oil rig, a capsized ship at the bottom of the sea. With these comes the same traps found in the original Tomb Raider, updated to fit within their modern worlds, and admittedly with a hint of the ridiculous - crates swinging with constant momentum and sandbags that fall at exactly the wrong moment, for instance. But suspend your disbelief and you can appreciate inventiveness in the name of maintaining a challenge.

The combat, too, has taken a bounding leap from the original’s simple point-and-shoot gunplay. With urban areas comes an army of human foes, each one armed with vicious weaponry, from basic lead pipes and pistols, to pump-action shotguns and flamethrowers, the last of these a one-hit kill if Lara isn’t careful. Now more than ever the combat is a ballet of gunplay and movement, where a split-second decision between offensive and defensive (and the best choice of weapon for each foe) can mean the difference between life and death. Underwater combat also makes its debut, adding a new breed of suspense as well as thrills.

Tomb Raider II remains the best-selling game in the series, and it’s a distinction that was well-earned. With the title, developers Core Design took their already-iconic adventurer to new heights, and while the story is predictably hit-or-miss, the production values are sky-high. Almost two decades after its initial release, the game remains a shining example of the action-adventure video game. Outstanding stuff.

Overall score: 6/10: Old Tomb Raider game with too much emphasis on combat.  There are other better Tomb Raider games from this era to play.  Probably worth it when on sale, but that's about it.

I may not be an expert tomb raider, but I have played through this one, number 3, and am currently part way through 4, so I have a decent idea of how the games work.  The reason I have not played the 1st one (officially) is that I decided to get the strory aspect from the newer Tomb Raider: Anniversary, which is the remake.  Given the discrepancy in game release dates and control schemes, it would be vastly unfair to compare it with the older games.

Firstly, the graphics have aged.  But then again, the game is released back in 1996, so I can let it pass, it was probably fine, maybe even mind blowing back then.

The controls and general gameplay are going to be the hardest to get a handle on when first starting.  In short, Lara controls almost exatcly like a tank.  Do not go in expecting to use a mouse and keyboard with the WSAD mentality, the game uses either ye olde joystick are keyboard only, and I'm not even 100% sure on the joystick.  However, it feels like part of the challenge and fun of the game comes from mastering the controls.

Level design is adequate.  I remember it was interesting to navigate and solve the environment puzzles, but I don't remember vast portions of the game, so nothing really left much of an impression.

Combat is bad.  The way Lara is controlled does not make combat easy in the first place.  This is complicated, especially in this game, when most of the enemies are in tight quarters, and many are armed with guns.  It makes it difficult to get through the game without guzzling many of the medkits you find.  Fortunately, many of the other games so far have far fewer armed enemies, which balances combat for the better.  I don't remember there being many bosses, it may only be restricted to one, but I'm finding that these Tomb Raider games have a habit of making boss fights rather difficult.

Story: I can't remember, so I'm not going to comment too much.  However, these games are rather short on dialogue, character development, narrative.  Mostly, just excuses to move you from location to location and get you into a level.  I'm fine with that, just don't go in expecting a novel masterpiece.

Finally, I couldn't get any of the graphical issues or FMV sequences corrected.  I didn't spend much time on it, but this one has more technical issues than the other games I've loaded so far.

Doors in this world are operated not by door handles, but huge levers located on the other side of the city.

reviewText:
Tomb Raider II brings back the iconic charismatic archaeologist, Lara Croft, on another epic journey around the globe to investigate the legend around the Dagger of Xian. Her second adventure takes her along the Great Wall of China, the snowy terrains of Tibet, Italy’s city of Venice and a sunken shipwreck, accompanied by more complex series of jumping puzzles and death traps, lever activated time puzzles and the merciless killing of treasure hunting goons and exotic animals that stand in her path.

The game grants Lara the ability to climb ladders and craggy walls, to roll in the air and underwater for trickier puzzles, and to drive vehicles such as speedboats and snowmobiles around certain levels in the game, which can be incredibly fun and very tedious at the same time. Flares have been thrown into the game to allow Lara to explore particularly dark areas with ease, which come in handy for some of the later levels, along with new weapons packing serious firepower like the M16 assault rifle, a grenade launcher and automatic dual pistols (which replace the dual magnums that were available in TR1), along with all weapons within the previous game.

Enemies now have the intelligence to climb surfaces in order to reach Lara and carry pretty damaging weaponry, making combat somewhat more difficult, especially when they corner the player in tight spaces. Meaning there will be more ammo to find, a few more medicine packs to collect, and there are 3 secrets to find throughout each level; the gold, jade and silver dragons.

For those who have played Tomb Raider I, you will be pleased to hear that instead of having to save your progress at a save crystal and having to restart tedious levels every time Lara plummets to her death from that point, Tomb Raider II allows you to save your progress from your save manual whenever and wherever. It makes life much, much easier.

All environments and graphics appear to have been enhanced both in colour and in quality in this game, ultimately keeping movable blocks and secret areas better hidden, so it’s very easy to overlook a potential secret or an area full of loot if you aren’t actively exploring the entire level. The soundtrack in the game has been heavily built off its predecessor, only playing on certain cues like when the protagonist steps into the path of a rolling boulder, as it did in the previous game.

Another change to be noted is the change in voice actress for our fearless protagonist. Personally, I felt that her new voice fitted Lara better as she sounds much more experienced and capable of handling herself like a badass, whereas, her voice in TR1 portrayed her to be more of an arrogant adolescent.

The tutorial area in Lara Croft’s manor has developed greatly from its elder. The crates blocking most of the large manor have now been removed, inviting the player to explore the charming home more thoroughly. The gymnasium and the swimming pool reappear in this game, but with much obstacles to manoeuvre through and a prettier pool to swim around in.

Here is where you are introduced to Winston, Lara’s old butler who is intent on following her around the house while groaning and carrying a tray of rattling tea cups. On the odd occasion when I accidently ran into him, there is a chance that he will break wind. It can be pretty fun for a while, but eventually having him dog you around the manor will grow tedious. My solution was to have him follow me to the meat locker in the kitchen, wait for him to follow a certain distance behind, then perform a well-timed leap out of the area, and lock him in. I found watching him try to walk through the door grunting and groaning to be quite amusing. Cruel, but amusing.

Lara can now venture outside the manor and explore the maze behind it. The main section behind the maze is an assault course the player can now test out their skills on obstacles that are a bit more challenging than the gym.

All in all, if you’re looking for a game where you can relax and enjoy shooting lead into your enemies, but still challenging enough that it keeps you wondering about any potential death traps around the corner, Tomb Raider II is a classic game with plenty of everything and is generally fun to play, even when using the Playstation controls, although the PC controls are much more fluid.

Fantastic platformer/ exploration game from the late 90's.

While slightly inferior to it's predecessor in terms of local, and with an overemphasis on human enemies and combat, Tomb Raider II maintains enough personality and varied level design of it's own to stand out and be a worthy successor.

This is how more games should be: Story takes a backseat, serving more as a pretext for Lara'a globe-trotting adventure. There are no horendous quite-time events, while cutscenes don't interrupt gameplay but feel more like a reward for conquering a set of levels.

Levels are open and vertical; unlike those in Tomb Raider III they flow quite well. Jumping and climbing are the focus here. The game is also much more colorful that Tomb Raider I which stuck with more of a grey/ brown palette. The pixelated pastel textures are quite nostaligic.

If you like solitary exploration, vertical level design and varied environments, this game is for you.

reviewText: NOTE:  I had to use a third party piece of software to be able to be able to map an XBox 360 pad in a sensible configuration.  I'd give this game a 7/10 score though because although it has many timeless elements of game design that still make it quite a bit of fun to play through, it does not have as clear and interesting a story as the first Tomb Raider, it falls short of that mark on most measures; and additionally it shows it's age graphically.  Is it still worth playing, yeah, but it could play much better with a bit of modernization.  The character model for Lara is of course excellently done for the time, as are her animations; but I think there may be more polygons in her model than in the rest of the game.  The modelling though isn't really where the game suffers;but rather in the low resolution textures.  The cut-scenes look extremely grainy on modern resolutions and the textures on the environments are sometimes poor enough to really pull you out of any immersion you may have.  I will say that there are a very wide variety of environments and some of them are quite in interesting, although if you're like me, you may not be able to clearly understand why you are actually going to all these peculiar places.  The story just isn't particularly clear or engaging.  The platforming controls are somewhat finicky.  You really end up using a set of manuevers in kind of the same way you might in a fighting game to clear these challenges.  Once you get those moves down, it's usually more a matter of finding where you need to platform to rather than the execution that is the challenge.  There are some block pushing/lever pulling puzzles as well and these are solid, usually not too much of a challenge but that's fine as they don't overstay their welcome.  As far as the combat, it's very similar to the first Tomb Raider as well, and the added weapon, and enemy variety is one of the real clear improvements over it's predecessor.  Overall, the game is dated, but fun.  If you are considering taking a look at the classic roots of the franchise though, I'd start with Tomb Raider 1 (better story, somewhat better level design, and native x-input support for the PC), and if you enjoy that .. heck yeah TR 2 is worth the time investment.

reviewText:
Tomb Raider II was a solid step forward for the early days of the Tomb Raider franchise, which was still in it's infancy back in 1997. In many ways it's a refinement of the first game, carrying on with the same jumping and switch-throwing basics, but dressing them up in more varied environments. The somewhat monotonous rocks and sand of the original are swapped out for interesting locales like an opera house and sunken ship, and in a small but important change, most stages feature an outdoor portion under a blue sky.

Lara herself has been given a big upgrade, with a brand new character model that better matches her promotional art. She finally gets to wear her iconic braid in-game, and her chest no longer looks like it could take your eye out. This game is also the start of costume changes for Lara, kicking off the tradition with a particularly famous wetsuit.

Lara's action repertoire is expanded with two new moves. She can climb ladders now, which feels like a natural addition to her moveset, and integrates just as smoothly into the game's level designs. The new flares that she carries are less successful. Though necessary on a few occasions, it's questionable whether they earn having their own dedicated button – but at least they produce a nice lighting effect.

On the downside, even in its second outing there are signs that classic Tomb Raider is showing its age. Its new environments are assembled from the same clumsy building blocks of the first game, resulting in some weird proportions in places like the interiors of Lara's home. More egregiously, the majority of the enemies Lara faces this time are human, but with no difference in AI from the animal enemies she fought the first time around. Equipped with guns, the new human foes are a lot more dangerous, but your best tactic is still to find a high ledge where you can shoot repeatedly at them, as they stupidly run around in confused circles below. Eventually these encounters feel like tiresome interruptions of the core gameplay.

Of course it's no surprise that Tomb Raider II is at its best when it's not focused on combat, and the series' particular brand of puzzle platforming is still excellent when it's left alone to do its thing. Some standout stages are the monastery (which is formed as a central hub surrounded by short platforming challenges) and the temple (a thorough gauntlet that will test all the skills you've accumulated).

With it's second game, the Tomb Raider series was hurriedly growing into the fame that it had fallen into unexpectedly. Some of its improvements were essential to defining the character of the franchise's early years, and most of what was fun about the first game carries over intact. But at the same time, it's clear that the original formula is already being stretched toward its limit – and the series' ongoing struggle to balance action with adventure was a problem right from the first sequel.

reviewText: This game is frustratingly designed, wonky, and really not a great game. That is, by modern design standards. If we were to go back, this would still not be a great game, but it is a good one. This dichotomy is because many of the things that people would find frustrating, were pretty regular in the early days of 3d games. Camera issues and artificial difficulty (from trying to find how to progress, trying to pull of a difficult jump while lara controls like a jumbo jet, or where a key is hidden) were common issues by todays standards and (if I remember correctly), were annoying back then, but we dealt with it, and while certain games do it better, TR 2 was a good action-puzzle-platformer. The key word is patience with this game. Have patience and you will be rewarded. Patience and saving every few minutes and before major jumps or action scenes. While its rewarding to solve a level, you will get stuck while you search for some way to get by. And those ways are usually super dumb. Now in the day this was just a ploy to sell strategy guides. Fortunately we have free strategy guides online, and unless you want to spend a long time on one section, you may have to use it. However, despite not aging well, if you can put up with the frustrating design of the time, it is a good long (although maybe for the wrong reasons) adventure. I'm going to recommend it for people who want to experience it. For people who want the best TR game though, I really do recommend Anniversary, its the adventure of the old games with more modern design.
